fields.summary: Crowd Directory Importer does not work when transfering data between two Internal Directories
Make sure that changing the Directories order will not remove the permission of the administrator
Upgrade trunk to AUI 2.2.2

fields.description:
In Crowd 1.x, SAL could store properties against arbitrary keys. As of 2.x, these keys are prepended with "plugin."
After migration, the "plugin.example" key is attempted to be read, but the "example" key is what's in the database.


Here is some example original data:
<salProperties>
   <salProperty>
     <key>example</key>
     <propertyName>some.property name</propertyName>
     <propertyValue>some property data<propertyValue>
   </salProperty>
   <salProperty>
     <key>null</key> <!-- null string is global scope -->
     <propertyName>com.atlassian.example:build</propertyName>
     <propertyValue>2</propertyValue>
   </salProperty>
fields.summary: Sal Properties data is inaccessible after migration

fields.description:
Currently crowd-api gets it dependency version of commons-collections from the version used in atlassian-core. This isn't ideal, and can lead to problems when depending on crowd-api in another library.

The ApplicationTemplate code uses a method which is only in commons-collections 3.2 and above, so crowd-api should definitely declare its dependency as this version of higher.
fields.summary: Declare dependency on commons-collections in crowd-api module

fields.description:
setProperty and getProperty have different logic for creating the key for a property.

Given keys "someKey" and "plugin.anotherKey" set will use the keys "someKey" "plugin.plugin.anotherKey" while get will use "plugin.someKey" for both keys. I think get's implementation is correct.
fields.summary: PluginPropertyManageGeneric creates property keys incorrectly

fields.description:
When trying to edit the "Configuration" of an existing internal directory, after pressing the "Update" button, receive a this error: IllegalTransactionStateException: Transaction is already completed - do not call commit or rollback more than once per transaction

In particular, I tried to change the "Maximum Invalid Password Attempts:" from zero (0) to five (5) by entering "5" in the text field. I then pressed the "Update" button. I received the IllegalTransactionStateException. When navigating back to the internal directory information I confirm that the value was not change from zero (0).

This IllegalTransactionStateException was also received when attempting to change the "Password History Count:" from zero (0) to twelve (12).

fields.description:
Currently Crowd makes a query for all the attributes on a given entity: role, group or user. This results in a very large dataset being returned for all searches, regardless of purpose.

At a minimum, we should only request attributes which are used by Crowd: the name, description and member attributes for groups and roles, and all the mapped attributes for users.

Even better would be to retrieve only the membership attributes when searching for memberships, only the group attributes when looking up groups, and so on.

The minimum requirement is quite easy to implement, and I'll attach a simple (completely untested) patch that I'd like to see tested in the future. The second option would be harder, requiring some redesign of the SpringLDAPConnector, which currently has only has one place where SearchControls objects are constructed for all LDAP searches.
fields.summary: Retrieve only the necessary attributes when searching for LDAP users and groups

fields.description:
User is added automatically to Crowd directory which is an Delegated LDAP authenticated directory when user try to access an application which is managed by Crowd.

More Explanation:
User is currently not a member of application "Y" which has Delegated LDAP directory "X". But when he try to access that application "Y" using his LDAP credentials he is added to that directory "X" automatically.

fields.description:
Currently, Confluence creates the user using 2 steps: 1st create an empty user; 2nd update the empty user fields with the rest of the user details. However, the Directory Password Regex is being checked against the empty user as well. Since the password field will be empty, the Regex Test will always fail.

fields.summary: Applications can't create Users in Crowd if an Internal Directory with Regex is being used for the App

fields.description:
Crowd's LDAP RemoteDirectory implementations throw ObjectNotFoundExceptions instead of the appropriate UserNotFoundException/GroupNotFoundException.

To make things even harder, the problem cannot be statically detected because ONFE is now a RuntimeException.

All of the RemoteDirectory LDAP implementations need to be reviewed and fixed accordingly, including unit tests and integration tests.
fields.summary: Crowd's LDAP RemoteDirectory implementations throw ObjectNotFoundExceptions

fields.description:
We need a new directory type for Confluence and JIRA LDAP integration. It should allow storage of attributes against local users, as well as local groups for LDAP users in Confluence.

Authentication and most other operations will still be delegated to LDAP, except where local data is specifically required.

The specification is under discussion (Atlassian-only) here:

https://studio.atlassian.com/wiki/display/EMBCWD/LDAP+Pony+Directory
fields.summary: Hybrid LDAP-Internal directory for local attributes and groups
Google Apps SAML complains that not enough space was allocated to hold decompressed data

fields.description:
Like FE-899

Set-up is something like this:
* SSO domain is .example.com
* Crowd-authenticated sites are \{wiki,bugs,crowd\}.example.com
* Additionally, webdav.example.com allows users to easily make test websites

Even though webdav.example.com is configured to only allow static content, JavaScript can still steal cookies (tested with {{<script>document.write(document.cookie)</script>}}).

Admittedly, the "correct" fix is to stick "trusted" content under a different subdomain (.secure.example.com) but that gets messy. Additionally, it's perfectly feasible to make webdav.example.com Crowd-authenticated but not wish for embedded JS to read the same cookies (this can be fixed by making webdav.example.com serve application/octet-stream, Content-Disposition: attachment and moving the "normal" server to webdav.example.net, but that's even messier).
fields.summary: crowd.token_key cookie should be HttpOnly

fields.description:
We have an open source project that's using jira, fisheye, and crowd for development but Drupal for it's website, forums, and blog. We current have to maintain two sets of user names and passwords for developers and any community member interested developing. It'd be great if there was a way to integrate the centralized administration and SSO features of Crowd with our Drupal project hub. I know we could use OpenID but it's cumbersome for non-technical users.

Would it be possible for Atlassian to write a Drupal application connector? With as many people that use Drupal, I think this connect would be really useful. Thanks.
fields.summary: Drupal Application Connector

fields.description:
This is less a product feature request than a request that Atlassian "eat it's own SSO dog food." 

As an Atlassian customer, there are a pile of logins I have to maintain. Off I'm not even sure how many I have, but off the top of my head, I know I have separate logins for:

forums.atlassian.com
confluence.atlassian.com
jira.atlassian.com
my.atlassian.com (sales & licensing)
studio.plugins.atlassian.com

I think Atlassian is generally quite good about using it's own products, and that makes for better products, but having 5 (and maybe more) logins to be a customer of Atlassian is a bit much. And (as a co-worker quipped), I think I know where you can get a single sign-on server. ;-)

Thanks.
fields.summary: It would be nice if Atlassian's own instsances of their apps used single sign on.

fields.description:
The WAR distribution should be distributed inside a zip file with it's dependencies.

atlassian-crowd-2.0.3/crowd.war
atlassian-crowd-2.0.3/lib/mail-1.4.jar
atlassian-crowd-2.0.3/lib/jta-1.0.1B.jar
atlassian-crowd-2.0.3/lib/activation-1.1.jar

Currently, you have to download both the WAR and Standalone distribution, just to get the right libs, and if you mistakenly unzip the .zip of the war, then you discover the .zip is actually a .war, and have to probably delete all the files/dirs it just created.
fields.summary: Crowd WAR distribution needs refinement

fields.description:
Crowd will need to be updated to use the new Embedded Crowd API's.

This means the following:
# Interfaces for Directory and Application
# Migration of core pieces of the Crowd-Embedded project into Crowd.
# Changes to types when we are dealing with Attributes on objects.
# More fin grained control of how we create, update and delete Directory Mappings and Group Mappings.
# The updating of the Console to use the updated calls regarding Directory and Application configuration.
fields.summary: Migrate Crowd to use the updated Crowd Embedded API's

fields.description:
The CrowdID server 'return_to' url is lost after logout/login

*Normal flow:* you are not logged in to CrowdID server (or logged in as 'user1'), then external site requests authentication for 'user1', redirects to CrowdID for authentication, CrowdID server logs the user in (or just checks the association if it is logged in) and redirects back to external app.

*Problematic flow:* The user is logged in to CrowdID as 'user2'. Then external site requests authentication for 'user1', redirects to CrowdID for authentication. CrowdID server suggests the user to logout and login back (which is correct). But, after logging in as correct user ('user1'), CrowdID server "forgets" that it has to return to requesting application that asked for authentication for 'user1'.
fields.summary: Store the openid auth request in session so that we can still process it
CrowdID Client does not trim spaces before and after the URL

fields.description:
We need to remove the dependency on Atlassian-User from Crowd so we can add one going the other way for Embedded Crowd.

Difficult, but not impossibly so.
fields.summary: Remove dependency on Atlassian-User

fields.description:
It's very common the cases when the LDAP entries are missing one of the mandatory attributes, like *email* or *displayName*.

Would be cool to be able to use macros to workaround this problem.

Example:

*Email:* $givenName.$sn@domain.com *or* $uid@domain.com (built using the other LDAP entry attributes)

*displayName:* $givenName $sn
fields.summary: Allow the LDAP connector to use macros when the LDAP entries do not have the necessary attributes

fields.description:
Currently, if a CrowdID user tries to authenticate and he does not have an Email, FirstName or LastName attribute in his LDAP entry, Crowd will show an exception in the Browser. Also, the log file shows that the problem happened when trying to add the new user entry to the DB and that the email was the problem, however it does not report clearly that the LDAP entry lacks the email attribute.

TODO:

1. Report an error message to the user instead of an exception.
2. Imporve logging report to make clear what was the root cause
fields.summary: Handle properly cases when CrowdID users do not have an Email/FirstName/LastName in the LDAP server

fields.description:
Example:

{noformat}
 ACCEPT: */*
 ACCEPT-ENCODING: identity
 VIA: 1.1 www-cacheF.example.com.au:8080 (squid/2.6.STABLE5)
 X-FORWARDED-FOR: 129.78.138.61, 179.78.64.103
 CACHE-CONTROL: no-cache, max-age=604800
 X-HOST: test.com
 X-FORWARDED-PROTO: http
{noformat}
fields.summary: Support HTTP X-Forwarded-For headers with more than one IP address

fields.description:
Currently, Crowd allows admins to define groups to which the new users will be added (CWD-770).

Would be good to be able to define rules/conditions that must be matched to add the users to the groups.

Example:

* And LDAP attribute is ==, <, >, != from value.
* LDAP Entry contains attribute XYZ
* etc
fields.summary: Allow Admins to define rules for the automatic Group membership

fields.description:
Please see original issue raised against Crowd Embedded:
https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/EMBCWD-209

We are seeing massive thread contention caused by all CrowdService operations constructing a new instance of RemoteDirectory via reflection.
fields.summary: DirectoryManagerGeneric will always create a new instance of RemoteDirectory on every call to any method.

{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 8 June 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hello everyone,

We have recently reviewed this issue and the overall interest in the problem. As the issue hasn't collect votes, watchers, comments, or support cases from many customers during its lifetime, it's very low on our priority list, and will not be fixed in the foreseeable future. That's why we've decided to resolve it as *Timed Out*.

Although we're aware the issue is still important to those of you who were involved in the conversations around it, we want to be clear in managing your expectations. The Crowd team is focusing on issues that have broad impact and high value, reflected by the number of comments, votes, support cases, and customers interested. Please consult the [Atlassian Bugfix Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-server-bug-fix-policy-201294573.html] for more details.

We understand how disappointing this decision may be, but we hope you'll appreciate our transparent approach and communication.

Atlassian will continue to watch this issue for further updates, so please feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Thank you,

Crowd Team
{panel}

fields.description:
The crowd token generation is based on multiple information from the client including User Agent header from the browser. For some reason IE8 occasionally decides to run in IE7 compatibility mode, and changes the User Agent header from MSIE 8.0 to MSIE 7.0. 
Crowd interprets it as a new browser and the user is not logged in.

See https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/AGMP-586

The fix that we commited to 1.7-studio branch can be found here:
https://atlaseye.atlassian.com/changelog/crowd/?cs=107741
fields.summary: IE8 can present an IE7 User-Agent string causing users to appear logged out

fields.description:
We noticed that crowd is still using XFire as framework instead of CXF, which is more or less XFire2.0.

This gives some problem in newer project which are already using CXF as their framework. One problem we had to overcome is the XmlSchema version needed for both CXF as XFire. Or that you need them both in your project which is a lot of unnecessary overhead. Can crowd been upgraded to CXF so that?

{code}
<dependency>
	<groupId>com.atlassian.crowd</groupId>
	<artifactId>crowd-integration-client</artifactId>
	<version>2.0.3</version>
	<exclusions>
		<exclusion>
			<groupId>org.apache.ws.commons</groupId>
			<artifactId>XmlSchema</artifactId>
		</exclusion>
	</exclusions>
</dependency>

<dependency>
	<groupId>org.apache.ws.commons.schema</groupId>
	<artifactId>XmlSchema</artifactId>
	<version>1.4.2</version>
</dependency>
{code}
fields.summary: upgrade XFire to CXF

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 20 July 2018|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hello everyone,

We’re happy to say that we are planning to deliver SAML support in Crowd.

Thanks for all your votes and comments. We’ve listened to your valuable feedback and decided to add this feature to our roadmap.

We’ll let you know once this is underway and will keep you updated throughout the process.

If you would like to participate in early validation of our solution please don't hesitate to get in touch with me directly.

Best regards,

Marek Radochonski
Senior Product Manager, Crowd
 [mradochonski@atlassian.com|mailto:mradochonski@atlassian.com]
 
{panel}

 

*Original description of the issue:*

I'm not sure if this is a support or feature request. I'd like to setup Postini to authenticate against Crowd via SAML. The only mention of Crowd+SAML I've heard of involves Google Apps. Does Crowd actually function as a general SAML service?

Fwiw, here's the Postini SSO docs:

[https://ac-s9.postini.com/help/admin_ee_cu/wwhelp/wwhimpl/common/html/wwhelp.htm?context=EEHelp&file=sso_toc.html#2973241]

I got so far as "Enter your SSO issuer ID and paste your SSO PEM (base64) format certificate" under "Configure SSO for Your Account Org".

Thanks!

fields.description:
Please support SSO for Sharepoint and Confluence.

Currently the SSO option available for using the Sharepoint Connector is using [JCIFS or Tomcat and IIS|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/SPCON/Configure+SharePoint+to+Use+the+Single+Sign+On+%28SSO%29+Service], both using a custom authenticator created for this purpose.

Having Crowd support SSO for Sharepoint and Confluence would provide an attractive work around for enterprise customers.
fields.summary: Support Sharepoint SSO with Sharepoint Connector plugin

fields.description:
We have a large jira instance (>200k stories)

We have 45k users

We CARE about performance of jira, and optimising crowd integration has made a decent impact.

We care aboure the file:
com.atlassian.crowd.integration.service.cache.CachingGroupMembershipManager

specifically the method
public boolean isMember(String userName, String groupName) throws RemoteException, InvalidAuthorizationTokenException

is very immature. There is even a ToDo in the source code to say unoptimised.

Optimising this method resulted in >50% of our calls to the crowd remote service being rendered useless.

Attached is a version currently undergoing testing
fields.summary: Optimise Crowd Client (osuser)- isMember

fields.summary: Please add support for SpringSecurity 3.0
Crowd Apache Connector doesn't escape svn path names when using them in regexps
Log the reason for failed SSO authentication on the client side

fields.description:
Currently, Crowd supports the PLAIN connection only.

The workaround to secure connections would be to use SSL (see how to improve performance [here|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWDKB/Performance+problems+after+setting+LDAP+Connector+to+use+SSL])

It depends on the DIGEST-MD5 support in SpringLDAP (available in 1.3.1): http://jira.springframework.org/browse/LDAP-173
fields.summary: Support AD SASL DIGEST-MD5

fields.description:
Crowd client libraries should replace the context class loader when using X-Fire as X-Fire relied on the context class loader to dynamically load classes.

This causes problems when used from a plugins 2.0 context the context class loader could be set to an OSGi loader instead of the loader that loaded the X-Fire classes.

See: https://extranet.atlassian.com/crucible/cru/CR-FE-3080 for workarounds other products have to implement to get around this problem.
fields.summary: Crowd client libraries should replace the context class loader when using X-Fire

fields.description: It would be great if Crowd could support wildcards in the IPs of trusted proxy servers, for example, {{127.0.0.\*}}.  This is useful in deployment situations where multiple tomcats, bound to port 8080 on different loopback interfaces, all starting with {{127.0.0.\*}}, are being served through mod proxy on Apache.
fields.summary: Support wildcards in the trusted proxy server configuration

fields.description:
When I add a group to another group, it doesn't immediately appear all the time.  The group that I just added the group to still has no group members on the "View Group" page.  If I go to the directory configuration page and flush the cache, the group membership then shows up correctly.

I do have LDAP caching configured (polling interval 300) on this directory, but since I'm making the change using Crowd, there's no reason the change can't immediately appear (and it's extremely confusing to my users not to have the change show up immediately).
fields.summary: Group membership changes in AD don't immediately appear

fields.description:
Currently, the alias feature is used between an Application and Crowd. It works fine when a user is already a member of the necessary Groups in the Directory (ie. LDAP).

However, if the user is not member of the groups or the Directory is read-only, the only option left is the Delegated Directory. The Administrator will have to apply the alias to each user and add the user to all the Groups that the user was member of in the Application.

*Example: Jira will be integrated with Crowd using LDAP. JIRA user names are different from the LDAP user names*

1. The Admin imports all the LDAP users into a Delegated Directory.
2. The Admin has to import all the JIRA Users and Groups from JIRA into the same Directory (to obtain all the JIRA Groups)
3. For each User, the Admin will have to:
3.1: create an alias to connect the JIRA user to the LDAP user.
3.2: add the LDAP user to all the groups that the JIRA user is member of.
3.3: remove the JIRA user from the Directory. 

*If the Alias feature was between Crowd and the Directory, the Admin would have only to:* 1. Import the JIRA Users to the Delegated Dir. 2. Add an alias to each user (the memberships would be already assigned to each user).
fields.summary: Allow user alias to be used between Crowd and the Directories

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Status as of 27 April 2011|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3C78B5| titleBGColor=#3C78B5| bgColor=#E7F4FA}

Hi folks,
 
Thanks for your feedback and continued support. We wanted to give you an update on the status of this issue.

Over the medium term, the direction we're taking with Crowd is to focus on scalability, reliability and performance. Exciting development has occurred and is going to continue within this space. This feature is a strong candidate for a future release. We can't promise a specific release, but we'll update the issue when we have more concrete information.
 
Regards,
Eugene Mak
Atlassian Product Management

{panel}

[http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Integrating+Crowd+with+Spring+Security] is written for SS 2.0. Now that 3.0 is out, it needs updating.

Update May 3rd 2012: This is now scheduled in for the next major release, Crowd 2.5. At this stage we don't have an expected release date for 2.5.

fields.description:
Here's how to replicate the problem I'm experiencing:

Setup a fresh 2.0.3 install using a internal directory.

Problem #1

* go to administration and disable "Authorisation Caching" (for good measure)
* add a new user to the directory
* go to groups > crowd-administrators > direct members and add the new user to the group
* log into the crowd console using the new user account
  -> this results in the "self service" console, not the admin console as expected
* restart crowd, then log into the crowd console using the new user account again
  -> after the restart you get the admin console

Problem #2

* remove the user from the crowd-administrators group
* go to applications > crowd > directories and change "Allow all to authenticate" to True
* log into the crowd console using the new user account
  -> this should result in self-service console, instead the user has admin privs
* restart crowd, then log back into the crowd console
  -> now the admin privs are gone and you'll see the self-service console

fields.description:
WAC admin contain(ed) the following code:
{code}
            // set the attributes of the principal
            SOAPAttribute[] soapAttributes = new SOAPAttribute[4];

            soapAttributes[0] = buildAttribute(RemotePrincipalConstants.EMAIL, email);
            soapAttributes[1] = buildAttribute(RemotePrincipalConstants.FIRSTNAME, firstName);
            soapAttributes[2] = buildAttribute(RemotePrincipalConstants.LASTNAME, lastName);

            principal.setAttributes(soapAttributes);
{code}
As you can see, at some point an attribute was removed but the array length not reduced.  This results in the following SOAP envelope from the 1.4.3 client:
{code:xml}

	    <token xmlns="http://authentication.integration.crowd.atlassian.com">HsWhzgaKmGencnVSJrleGw00</token>
	 </ns1:in0>
	 <ns1:in1>
	    <ID xmlns="http://soap.integration.crowd.atlassian.com">-1</ID>
	    <active xmlns="http://soap.integration.crowd.atlassian.com">true</active>
	    <attributes xmlns="http://soap.integration.crowd.atlassian.com">

		  <name>mail</name>
		  <values>

		  </values>
	       </SOAPAttribute>
	       <SOAPAttribute>
		  <name>givenName</name>
		  <values>

		  </values>
	       </SOAPAttribute>

fields.description:
When the User does not exist in the Delegated Directory and Crowd finds him in LDAP, the user is correctly added to Crowd's DB, however, the JIRA App Cache is not Updated.

*Possible consequences:*
# The user can login, but will not be a member of the *jira-users* group
# Sometimes the user can't login

\\
*Steps to Reproduce:*
# Delete the test user from Crowd delegatedDirectory. The directory is configured to automatically add jira-users group membership on new user creation in the local group memberships directory.
# Restart Crowd, JIRA, and start up Confluence. We log into JIRA as an administrator account, and view the user browser. The test user is not present. Log out of the administrator account, and then log in with the test user.
# The test user authenticates, but does not gain group membership of jira-users. The user does belong to confluence-users, however.
# The test user then authenticates to Confluence. This is successful, and the user belongs to both jira-users and confluence-users.
# The test user logs out of JIRA, and back into JIRA, but still does not have jira-users membership. Verifying in Crowd, the user now exists and owns both jira-users and confluence-users.
# After restarting JIRA, the test user can now log into JIRA, and has membership of both groups.
fields.summary: Crowd Integration Cache for JIRA is not updated
Users created using the Integration Library have details set to the default value of "-"
Message "Cannot find web resource module for: com.atlassian.auiplugin:dialog" is logged, but aui components are working fine

fields.description:
Currently, since Crowd 2.X versions have a new database schema, an XML backup is mandatory to be able to upgrade from 1.X versions to 2.X.

This procedure may not be possible for Big instances.
fields.summary: Allow Crowd to be upgraded from 1.X to 2.X without an XML Backup

fields.description:
I downloaded and printed the [PDF version|http://confluence.atlassian.com/download/attachments/23855134/CROWD-2-0-20090730-PDF.pdf] of the Crowd documentation. (Yes, there are people who RTFM, even if it's "just" 36% of us ;-) )

Alas, it's 504 pages long (wow!) and there is not a single page number anywhere.

Having page numbers would be a big help, even just for punching and filing the printout. Another huge benefit on top of that would be, if the cross references (the links) could use page numbers as well in the PDF version. That would really help offline reading.

(PS: Thanks for writing the docs in the first place!)
fields.summary: Add page numbers to the PDF version of the documentation

fields.description:
There are a few improvements we'd like to make to the Crowd model API to clean it up for direct use in other applications.

Some may be breaking changes; we'll need to see how these work out as we go.
fields.summary: Improve Crowd API for embedded usage

fields.description:
When attempting to create a user or change a password over a non-SSL connection, you'll get a cryptic error (which is tenuously connected in the documentation to the fact that you need to configure an SSL connection).  I think it would be much better if Crowd simply informed the user that it was not possible to take these actions over a non-SSL LDAP connection.

The error I get in this case is this:

Entity Invalid: [com.atlassian.crowd.integration.model.user.UserTemplateWithAttributes@45f778[name=another.test,directoryId=32770,active=true,emailAddress=anothertest@demiurgestudios.com,firstName=Another,lastName=Test,displayName=Another Test,iconLocation=]] with error: [LDAP: error code 53 - 0000001F: SvcErr: DSID-031A0FC0, problem 5003 (WILL_NOT_PERFORM), data 0 ]; nested exception is javax.naming.OperationNotSupportedException: [LDAP: error code 53 - 0000001F: SvcErr: DSID-031A0FC0, problem 5003 (WILL_NOT_PERFORM), data 0 ]; remaining name 'cn=another.test, OU=All Users,OU=Demiurge,DC=DEMIURGE,DC=LOCAL'
fields.summary: Error when refusing to add a user or change a password over a non-SSL Active Directory connection is uninformative

fields.description: I'm attempting to integrate subversion authentication with Crowd. When running the tests for Apache-CrowdAuth-1.2.3 I received the attached error (error.txt). The problem appears to be that Apache-CrowdAuth-1.2.3/blib/lib/Apache/CrowdAuth.pm fails to correctly detect my mod_perl version on line 41 because the error is being issued inside the else statement on line 62. As I am not a perl guru, my admittedly crude solution was to comment out the code that I didn't need. My changes to the file are detailed in the attached patch file (CrowdAuth.patch). After making this change the output from the tests is attached in the file success.txt
fields.summary: Tests for Apache-CrowdAuth-1.2.3 fail to detect mod_perl version
Provide option to create AD security groups instead of distribution groups

fields.description:
The most normal way to create a directory is to fill in all of the details for the directory, then click "test connection", then if that works, click "update" to actually create the directory.  Unfortunately, the "password" field is blanked out by the "test connection" button, meaning that I created several directories with no password set (which led to a cryptic error; see CWD-1785) and it took me a while of fumbling before I learned that that was the problem with the directories I created.

It seems that it would be most straightforward if the "test connection" button left a value in the "password" field if there was one in it when the button was clicked (i.e. for a new directory or a changing password).

Cheers!
fields.summary: Easy to create an AD directory with no password

fields.description:
The Console lets a user enter in an XML file from a newer version of Crowd say 2.1 and enter it into an older version (2.0.2).

This can lead to potentially weird issues and should not be allowed, e.g. renaming a RemoteDirectory.
fields.summary: The Crowd Console currently allows a user to restore XML data from a 'newer' version of Crowd into an older version

fields.description:
The documentation at http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWDKB/_Error+when+browsing+users,+groups+or+roles+for+Active+Directory indicates that the naming exception can be solved by using a FQDN for the AD server.  I was using an IP address for my AD server and got this error (and continued to get it when I changed to an IP address).

The error went away for me when I retyped the password for the AD user I was using to log in -- I either got it wrong the first time I typed it in, or it had wound up blank.  I think that page should be updated to indicate that that's another possible problem if you see that error.

Cheers.
fields.summary: Documentation answer for LDAP error is wrong

fields.description: We need to have a -XX:MaxPermSize=256m in the setenv.bat files. The setting is present in the .sh files.
fields.summary: Distribution setenv.bat files are mising MaxPermSize setting.

fields.description:
If a user has configured aliasing for a username, one can login with both the original username, and the alias username in Confluence.  In JIRA, you can _only_ use the alias.

Should we make Crowd more consistent and have it reject the non-alias username so that users must use the alias username associated per application?
fields.summary: Crowd should only accept the aliased user ID during authentication in Confluence

fields.description:
The UI for migrating users from one directory to another, should allow for an option to not migrate passwords.

This potentially leads to a problem where users would need to 'reset' there password, or potentially for the administrator to allow for the specification of a default password.
fields.summary: Allow the directory importer to take a configuration option to not import passwords.

fields.description:
Currently we are unique when counting users against a license based on directory id and user name.

If a customer sets up crowd to have multiple configurations for the same LDAP repository it is possible that a single user can be counted twice.

Perhaps we should change the LicenseResourceEntity to be based on user-name and (LDAP repository URL or base DN).
fields.summary: Users can be duplicated in license counts if Crowd is setup with multiple links to the same external (LDAP) directory.

fields.description:
The idea of self-escalation in security access has a growing number of proponents.  The theory is that you allow users to grant themselves increase or additional role/group access and get it so they can get on with what they need to do.  There is then a management audit step (e.g. notification) about the access granted.  

In the simplest form for crowd, certain roles or groups could allow the user to add themselves and the administrator would be notified.  The ability to indicate which roles this applied to would be critical since certain ones (e.g. finance related perhaps) would not allow self-add.   

More complex logic about which roles or groups could self-add into which other roles or groups would be a powerful next step (e.g if you are in the development group, you could self-add to various dev roles but not to marketing roles and vice versa.)

Most enforcement of poor employee choices for self-add is expected to be handled outside of the system but a simple check-box to disable self-add permissions for specific users might also be a good version 1 feature. (as well, of course, enabled/disabling it system wide)
fields.summary: Allow user to self-add to certain roles (or groups) with management notification/audit

fields.description: Please, please, please, configure stand-alone Crowd so that it runs as an unprivileged user out of the box.  If that can't be done or as a stop-gap until it can be done, provide documentation on how to do this.

fields.description:
When I configured our Google Apps test domain to use the Crowd Google Apps connector the initial certificate exchange crashed EAC Crowd.  The logs have rotated since then (2009-10-26), so I don't have specifics.  I believe Dave Cheney looked at the logs during the crash, so you might want to check with him.  

I can remove the certificate and/or completely disable SSO in our Google Apps test domain and try to crash EAC Crowd again if it will help you pinpoint the problem.  We'll just need to pick a good time to do it.

fields.description:
During the product installation, Crowd detects the current domain and IP being used and add them to Remote Addresses list (hosts/URLs that can access Crowd).

If the current machine has 2 Network Interface Cards, it is possible that Crowd will identify the IP from one of them during the installation, however will try to access the App server using the other. One of the IPs will not be added to the Remote Address list and will be blocked when trying to access Crowd.

*Workaround*
To avoid problems during the installation, please use the default URL http://localhost:8095/crowd at the Setup Wizard [Step 6|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Running+the+Setup+Wizard#RunningtheSetupWizard-Step6.Options].
fields.summary: Add support to Machines with multiple Network Interface Cards

fields.summary: Regression in performance on trunk

fields.description:
Hello,

nested groups that don't belong to the scope defined by the Base DN will not be resolved properly by the integration client.
I suspect that although the nested groups are qualified in the directory as distinguished names, the BaseDN (which is not ancestor to the nested group) filter will be applied and thus no data is returned to the client application.

I would recommend mentioning this detail explicitly in the documentation as well as lifting this limitation in a future iteration of Crowd.


Best Regards,
Edoardo
fields.summary: Incomplete memberships if nested groups are not childeren of Base DN

fields.description:
Currently the [Crowd LDAP Caching documentation|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Configuring+Caching+for+an+LDAP+Directory] states:
{quote}
Limitations
...
*Renaming objects is not supported.* — If the DN of an object is changed externally, the cache will be out of date until flushed.
{quote}

If an object is changed using an external tool, Crowd will report the following in the logs:
{noformat}
2009-11-16 16:55:46,911 http-8095-Processor24 ERROR [codehaus.xfire.handler.DefaultFaultHandler] Fault occurred!
org.springframework.ldap.NameNotFoundException: [LDAP: error code 32 - 0000208D: NameErr: DSID-031001CD, problem 2001 (NO_OBJECT), data 0, best match of:
	'OU=sydney,OU=australia,OU=oceania,OU=ABC,DC=COMMON,DC=AU,DC=UUJT,DC=DOMAIN,DC=com'
 nested exception is javax.naming.NameNotFoundException: [LDAP: error code 32 - 0000208D: NameErr: DSID-031001CD, problem 2001 (NO_OBJECT), data 0, best match of:
	'OU=sydney,OU=australia,OU=oceania,OU=ABC,DC=COMMON,DC=AU,DC=UUJT,DC=DOMAIN,DC=com'
 remaining name 'cn=John.Smith,ou=1122,ou=users,OU=ABC,DC=COMMON,DC=AU,DC=UUJT,DC=DOMAIN,DC=com'
	at org.springframework.ldap.support.LdapUtils.convertLdapException(LdapUtils.java:171)
	at org.springframework.ldap.core.LdapTemplate.executeWithContext(LdapTemplate.java:800)
	at org.springframework.ldap.core.LdapTemplate.executeReadOnly(LdapTemplate.java:783)
	at org.springframework.ldap.core.LdapTemplate.lookup(LdapTemplate.java:881)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.directory.connector.SpringLDAPConnector.findEntityByDN(SpringLDAPConnector.java:994)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.directory.cache.CachingLDAPDirectory.findEntityIdentifierFromDN(CachingLDAPDirectory.java:220)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.directory.cache.CachingLDAPDirectory.findGroupAndDirectMembersByName(CachingLDAPDirectory.java:331)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.directory.cache.CachingLDAPDirectory.findGroupByName(CachingLDAPDirectory.java:451)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.directory.cache.CachingLDAPDirectory.findGroupByName(CachingLDAPDirectory.java:470)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.application.ApplicationServiceGeneric.findGroupByName(ApplicationServiceGeneric.java:654)
{noformat}

A better implementation would consider:
1. The time necessary to synchronize the Forest Domains
2. If the Full DN can't be found, search for the object CN or Simplified DN (John.Smith@ad.domain.com)
3. Show to the Admin what are the cache inconsistencies so that he can flush the cache or force a Domain Sync.
fields.summary: Update LDAP Cache elements that had thier DN changed using an external tool

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 8 June 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hello everyone,

We have recently reviewed this issue and the overall interest in the problem. As the issue hasn't collect votes, watchers, comments, or support cases from many customers during its lifetime, it's very low on our priority list, and will not be fixed in the foreseeable future. That's why we've decided to resolve it as *Timed Out*.

Although we're aware the issue is still important to those of you who were involved in the conversations around it, we want to be clear in managing your expectations. The Crowd team is focusing on issues that have broad impact and high value, reflected by the number of comments, votes, support cases, and customers interested. Please consult the [Atlassian Bugfix Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-server-bug-fix-policy-201294573.html] for more details.

We understand how disappointing this decision may be, but we hope you'll appreciate our transparent approach and communication.

Atlassian will continue to watch this issue for further updates, so please feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Thank you,

Crowd Team
{panel}
 

Greetings, 

I've noticed this issue in the past, but didn't know what was causing it until I sat down to figure it out today.  

When an entry is created in an OpenLDAP-backed directory, it is generally given a schema with only the objectClass of inetOrgPerson.  This works sufficiently in a standalone configuration, but as soon as the directory is used more exhaustively, problems arise.  

Here is the Apache DS console output created while adding the posixAccount objectClass and it's MUST attributes to an entity created by Crowd:

{noformat}
#!RESULT ERROR
#!CONNECTION ldap://dev.itdatabase.com:389
#!DATE 2009-11-27T16:15:37.605
#!ERROR [LDAP: error code 20 - modify/add: objectClass: value #0 already exists]
dn: cn=brian,ou=people,dc=itdatabase,dc=com
changetype: modify
add: uid
uid: topping
-
add: gidNumber
gidNumber: 500
-
add: objectClass
objectClass: top
objectClass: posixAccount
-
add: homeDirectory
homeDirectory: /home/topping
-
{noformat}

This leads to #!ERROR [LDAP: error code 20 - modify/add: objectClass: value #0 already exists]

With some experimentation, it's clear that this failure does not occur if the entity is created with all the inheritors of inetOrgPerson.  This is true for both JXplorer and Apache DS Studio, so it is not like this is a problem isolated to a single browser.

Would it be possible for Crowd to start creating entities with the top, person and organizationalPerson objectClasses as well?
fields.summary: Crowd creates insufficient schema in new user entities with OpenLDAP

fields.summary: Confluence problems fetching Crowd data when following the Here Be Dragons instructions

fields.description:
Currently, the Crowd Atlassian Importer supports cases when the Users and Groups are in the Local database.

However, Confluence allows Groups to be in its local DB and Users to be in LDAP. In this case, when users login to Confluence for the first time, they would be added to the *external_entities* table and its memberships will be added to *external_members* table.

Currently, the Atlassian imported does not access these tables to import users and their memberships.

Problem: If these users are in LDAP, Confluence will not provide easy access to their details (ie. Email, Full Name, etc)
fields.summary: Atlassian Importer should support cases when Groups are in the local Database and users are in LDAP

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, when the user password expires (Internal Directory users) and the user try to login to Crowd, he will be automatically directed to his self-service console to change the password.

h3. Suggested Solution

It would be great if Crowd could notify the users by email when their passwords are about to expire (10, 5, 1 days before) and then send an email when the password has finally expired.
fields.summary: Notify users by email when their passwords are about to expire and when they are already expired

fields.description:
Currently, Crowd must be restarted if the Log Level of a package is changed in the log4j.properties file.

To avoid having to restart production instances only to have the new log configurations working, it would be great to be able to change them at any time for any package without having to restart.

Confluence already allows it: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Configuring+Logging
fields.summary: Allow Crowd to dynamically change the log level for any package

fields.description:
To Reproduce:

1-) Create a new LDAP Connector and provide all the necessary fields (including the password)
2-) Before saving (_Continue_ button), click on the _Test Connection_ button.
3-) If the connection is successful (don't click _Continue_ until it is successful) click Continue.
4-) Go to the Users menu and try to search. The following error will be displayed:

{noformat}
Uncategorized exception occurred during LDAP processing; nested exception is javax.naming.NamingException: [LDAP: error code 1 - 00000000: LdapErr: DSID-0C090627, comment: In order to perform this operation a successful bind must be completed on the connection., data 0, vece�]; remaining name 'dc=sydney, dc=atlassian, dc=com'
{noformat}

5-) To fix the problem, go to the Connector, provide a password and then click _Update_
6-) Try to search Users again; the search will work without any problem.
fields.summary: LDAP Connectors are saved without the User DN password if the *Test Connection* button is used before saving

BACKGROUND
================
We are standardising the Supported Platforms pages so that we present the information in a consistent way across all the products. To that end, we need to change the layout of the Crowd "System Requirements" page and related pages.

See internal specification page:
https://extranet.atlassian.com/display/TECHWRITING/Supported+Platforms+Page+Design

Affected Crowd documentation:
* Re-usable page:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/_System+Requirements+-+Software
* Main "system requirements" page -- includes the above page:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/System+Requirements
* CrowdID WAR installation page -- includes the above page:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Installing+CrowdID+WAR+Distribution
* Crowd WAR installation page -- includes the above page:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Installing+Crowd+WAR+Distribution
* Crowd WAR on JBoss installation page -- includes the above page:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Installing+Crowd+WAR+on+JBoss

==================

* TO DO AT LAUNCH: Change the page inclusions on all pages so that they include the real page, not the copy.

** http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Copy+of+_System+Requirements+-+Software
** http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Copy+of+System+Requirements

** http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/_WAR+Installation+JARs

* TO DO AT LAUNCH: Remember to *change the name* of this page to "*Supported Platforms*":
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/System+Requirements

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Status as of 27 April 2011|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3C78B5| titleBGColor=#3C78B5| bgColor=#E7F4FA}

Hi folks,
 
Thanks for your continued support and feedback, we wanted to give you an update on the status of this issue.
 
Over the medium term, the direction we're taking with Crowd is to focus on scalability, reliability and performance. Unfortunately, it means that this feature is unlikely to be included in any near-term improvements to the product, as workflows and user management don't align with our future direction.
 
We are aware of the issue, and recognise that it is something that needs to be done, however, it's unrealistic that it will ship within the next 12 months.
 
Regards,
Eugene
Atlassian Product Management

{panel}

In Crucible/Fisheye, our users would very much like to change their avatars. Problem is that company's security policy prevents us from connecting to an external server such as gravatar. 
However, we don have confluence and crowd as well, so it seems logical to be able to have the confluence avatars in crucible as well.
Feature request is therefor to forward avatars defined in confluence to the other supported atlassian crowd products that use avatars.
fields.summary: forward avatars from confluence to fisheye/crucible
